Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2014 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Jeffrey Meier is "Low-Dimensional Topology: Exceptional Dehn Surgery, Knot Concordance, and Doubly Slice Knots." The host institution for the fellowship is Indiana University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Charles Livingston.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the PostDoctoral Research Fellowship pertaining to this Project Outcomes Report was to use knot theory, which is the study of knotted curves in three-dimensional space, to study three-dimensional and four-dimensional manifolds, which can be thought of as variants of the familiar three-dimensional spatial realm we inhabit and the four-dimensional space-time that forms the basis of modern physics.  The PI proposed a two-pronged approach in this endeavor: the study of doubly slice knots and the study of Dehn surgery.  Not only has significant progress been made by the PI with respect to each aspect of this approach, but the research program of the PI also grew during the period of the Fellowship to encompass novel approaches that have led to exciting new ideas in the study of three-dimensional and four-dimensional manifolds.  Foremost among these new approaches are the theories of trisections and bridge trisections.

 

Just as a curve can be knotted in three-dimensional space, it turns out that a two-dimensional sphere can be knotted in four-dimensional space.  A knot is called slice if it is a cross-section of a knotted sphere, and a knot is called doubly slice if it is a cross-section of an unknotted sphere. Thus, the study of slice knots and doubly slice knots represents an important aspect of our evolving understanding of the interplay between three-dimensional and four-dimensional topology.  Building on results in his PhD thesis, the PI completed a number of projects related to the study of slice and doubly slice knots.  These include: a near-classification of doubly slice knots with at most 12 crossings with Charles Livingston (Indiana University), a proof that slice knots never admit a reducible surgery with three non-trivial summands, and an investigation of fibered, homotopy-ribbon knots with Kyle Larson (The University of Texas at Austin).

 

Dehn surgery is the process of removing a tubular neighborhood of a knot from three-dimensional space before re-gluing it in a novel way to produce a new three-manifold. This operation is sensitive enough to interact significantly with the underlying geometries of three-manifolds, yet robust enough that, when applied to links, encapsulates all of three-dimensional and four-dimensional topology.  In addition to the aforementioned result about reducible Dehn surgery on slice knots, the PI completed a number of projects related to the study of Dehn surgery on links.  Most importantly, connections between Dehn surgery on links and the burgeoning theory of trisections were established with Trent Schirmer (University of Georgia) and Alexander Zupan (University of Nebraska-Lincoln), and later codified in further work with Zupan.   These works connect the nascent theory of trisections with the 50-year-old Andrews-Curtis Conjecture, which has been major open problem in both low-dimensional topology and combinatorial group theory.

 

One of the most important ways to understand a four-manifold is to study knotted surfaces lying therein. From this vantage point, the four-manifold can be distinguished from other four-manifolds in subtle ways. Moreover, by considering various surgery operations, one can pass between four-manifolds using knotted surfaces, just as one can pass between three-manifolds by considering Dehn surgery on knots and links.  The PI and Zupan introduced the theory of bridge trisections, which offers a new approach to the study of knotted surface in four-manifolds.  In the classical setting of four-space, this offers a new diagrammatic calculus for studying the four-dimensional analogue of knot theory. In the more general setting of arbitrary four-manifolds, this allows for knotted surfaces to be studied in ways that are analogous with important, powerful techniques in three-dimensional topology.

 

The Fellowship allowed the PI to be involved in undergraduate education at Indiana University in a number of ways.  First, together with Corrin Clarkson, the PI created and oversaw a Directed Reading Program within the Indiana University Mathematics Department.  This program paired graduate student mentors with undergraduate participants in semester-long reading programs aimed at introducing the participants to advanced mathematics that would normally fall outside of the department curriculum.  The participants benefitted from the grad-school-like atmosphere of the program, while the mentors gained valuable experience in mathematical communication and research oversight.  Secondly, the PI supervised two summer research projects through the Indiana University Research Experience for Undergraduates program.  Both participants went on to PhD programs at major research universities. Finally, the PI participated in the Indiana University Minority Serving Institutions STEM Initiative, a partnership between IU and a collection of Historically Black Colleges and Universities aimed at increasing the number of African-American graduate students, scholars, and professionals in the STEM disciplines.   This was in addition to the usual research community activities, including conference travel, international collaboration, working with graduate students, giving seminar talks, organizing conferences, and refereeing papers.
